Award.AwardTitle: Assembly and Function of the Cyanobacterial Photosystem II Complex

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Intellectual Merit:
If carbon-neutral energy and chemical feedstock solutions are to be developed, these will likely include natural or engineered photosynthetic organisms that manufacture valuable products and/or engineered devices that mimic the principals of natural photosynthesis by coupling of light capture to charge separation and then to endergonic chemical bond rearrangement. An understanding of oxygenic photosynthesis is important on both counts. Despite much progress, there are many important facets of the photosynthetic mechanism that remain to be understood. Of central importance is the water oxidation mechanism catalyzed by photosystem II (PSII), which utilizes water as the source of reductant to fix inorganic carbon. Many aspects of the enzyme's oxygen-yielding water oxidation mechanism remain poorly understood. This includes the repair processes necessitated by incessant photodamage sustained by PSII. These photodamage processes are due to the extraordinary high-potential multi-electron redox reactions that PSII catalyzes; also an important consideration for natural and biomimetic solar energy applications. This proposal addresses two major questions: First, is there a signal conveying the occurrence of damage to an individual PSII complex thereby targeting it for repair or is the repair process a generalized response randomly operating on the population of PSII in response to photodamage-inducing conditions? Second, how are the active site metals, manganese and calcium, assembled into a catalytically active complex? The project will combine molecular genetic, biochemical and biophysical approaches to understand the D1 protein repair process and the assembly and function of the catalytically active complex and also the role of the proteins that tune its reactivity and organize its structure.

Broader Impacts:
Immersing high school science teachers in a research environment that will be combined with professional development activities will help educators gain an explicit view of how scientific knowledge is generated and will also help with their own curriculum development. Teacher participants will be trained to conduct research and mentor students. They will perpetuate this acquired knowledge with their students by implementing new content knowledge and pedagogical skills into their existing curriculum, mentoring students in student research projects and coaching students in science fair competitions. During state and national conferences teachers will share their developed curriculum and mentoring skills with other educators. The PI and Co-PI will disseminate the science research findings and the educational outreach experience at science and education conference, presenting at the OSU National Lab Day, and through research and practitioner journals.

ProgramReference.Text: RET SUPP-Res Exp for Tchr Supp
EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
If carbon-neutral energy and chemical feedstock solutions are to be developed, these will likely include: 1.) natural or engineered photosynthetic organisms that produce valuable products; 2.) engineered devices that mimic the principals of natural photosynthesis.  An understanding of oxygenic photosynthesis is important on both counts and has great intellectual merit as well as broader societal impacts.  The base of this process involves the reaction that plants, algae, and cyanobacteria use sunlight to split (oxidize) water to obtain the hydrogens necessary for food and energy production and yield oxygen as a by-product and is catalyzed by photosystem II (PSII).   The project involved basic research and had an educational component involving opportunities for high school teachers.   Teachers joined the lab during the summer, partnered with future teachers still training at the university, and worked with the scientists in the lab to contribute to the research effort and to get additional training in science curriculum development through a unique program with the College of Education.

The basic research project made progress towards the mechanism of water-oxidation by PSII using a combination of molecular genetic and biophysical techniques to probe the inner workings of PSII.  Contributions in two main areas were made.

First, new insights were obtained on the critical dioxygen (O2) forming step, which is the most difficult part of the catalytic process of water-splitting.  A highlight was the discovery of the unexpected role of the so-called second sphere active site ligands in tuning the reactivity of the metal cluster (Mn4CaO5) responsible for the water-splitting reaction. 

Secondly, progress was made towards understanding the self-repair mechanisms that are necessary to sustain oxygenic photosynthesis in the face the incessant for the damage that occurs in PSII due to the extraordinary high potential multi-electron redox reactions that PSII catalyzes.  The repair process is fascinating problem of metalloprotein assembly involving the stepwise building of the Mn4CaO5 metal cluster. Here, the photochemical reaction center is harnessed to perform the photooxidative assembly of the metal I’m system slowcluster.  Preliminary evidence for a new model of metal assembly was developed and continued research will specifically address this model. 

On the education side: effective formula for partnering in-service teachers with preservice teachers was developed and forms an excellent template for providing useful research opportunities for teachers that can be transmitted to local high schools for improved science education.


Last Modified: 04/26/2018
Modified by: Robert L Burnap

Image
  • The project obtained new insights into the way that the amino acids and water molecules surrounding the manganese metal cluster (Mn4CaO5) tune its reactivity in a way allowing the energetically demanding water-splitting reaction to occur.
    Rob Burnap

    A view of the photosystem II manganese cluster and its protein environment.

An understanding of oxygenic photosynthesis is important on both counts and has great intellectual merit as well as broader societal impacts. The base of this process involves the reaction that plants, algae, and cyanobacteria use sunlight to split (oxidize) water to obtain the hydrogens necessary for food and energy production and yield oxygen as a by-product and is catalyzed by photosystem II (PSII). The project involved basic research and had an educational component involving opportunities for high school teachers. Teachers joined the lab during the summer, partnered with future teachers still training at the university, and worked with the scientists in the lab to contribute to the research effort and to get additional training in science curriculum development through a unique program with the College of Education. The repair process is fascinating problem of metalloprotein assembly involving the stepwise building of the Mn4CaO5 metal cluster. Here, the photochemical reaction center is harnessed to perform the photooxidative assembly of the metal I?m system slowcluster. Preliminary evidence for a new model of metal assembly was developed and continued research will specifically address this model. On the education side: effective formula for partnering in-service teachers with preservice teachers was developed and forms an excellent template for providing useful research opportunities for teachers that can be transmitted to local high schools for improved science education.
